title: 115_s3502
content:
The "AI in Government Act of 2018" is the short title of this Act. It includes definitions for various terms used in the legislation. The Act defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, Board, Executive agency, institution of higher education, nonprofit organization, and Policy Lab. The Act establishes an Emerging Technology Policy Lab. The Emerging Technology Policy Lab advises and promotes the use of emerging technologies by the Federal Government, including artificial intelligence, for the public's best interest. It also aims to enhance cohesion and competency in Federal agency rule-making and technology utilization by convening various stakeholders to discuss recent developments. The Emerging Technology Policy Lab advises Federal agencies on programs and initiatives, provides technical insight on emerging technologies, identifies educational opportunities, and studies challenges related to the use of artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies by the Federal Government. The Policy Lab supports Federal agencies with programs and initiatives, enhances industry leadership in emerging technology, and promotes joint initiatives among various entities. The Administrator provides staff, resources, and administrative support, including hiring temporary employees and fellows. The Policy Lab appoints fellows from various organizations to participate, and may detail employees to Executive agencies. The OMB and OSTP coordinate with the Administrator and the Board on policy opportunities and challenges related to emerging technologies. The Administrator is required to submit a report to Congress. The Administrator must report annually to Congress on the Policy Lab's activities, including projects with Federal agencies, recommendations for supporting emerging technologies, and joint initiatives. All functions of the Emerging Citizen Technology Office will be transferred to the Policy Lab. The assets, obligations of the Emerging Citizen Technology Office will be transferred to the Policy Lab. Any reference to the Emerging Citizen Technology Office shall be deemed a reference to the Policy Lab. SEC. 4. ADVISORY BOARD. The Administrator will establish an advisory board to advise on Policy Lab issues and inform priorities and projects. The Board will be co-chaired by the Administrator and the Secretary of Commerce, with members from various federal agencies. The advisory board for Policy Lab will consist of members designated by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget and co-chairs of the Board, including representatives from industries, institutions of higher education, and public interest groups. Members must have expertise in emerging technologies or technology policy. The Board for Policy Lab meets at least once every 12 months and publishes an annual list of areas in the Federal Government needing technical expertise. Board members serve without compensation but may receive travel expenses. The Board is exempt from the duration requirements of the Federal Advisory Committee Act. SEC. 5. REPORT.

Within 6 months of this Act's enactment, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, with the Administrator, must submit a report to specific Senate and House committees. The report will outline the Federal Government's investment, development, and use of artificial intelligence, and how it aligns with existing data strategies of Federal agencies.

SEC. 6. UPDATE OF OCCUPATIONAL SERIES FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE. SEC. 6. UPDATE OF OCCUPATIONAL SERIES FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will identify key skills and competencies needed for AI positions and establish or update occupational series related to artificial intelligence. SEC. 7. SUNSET. Sections 3 and 4 of this Act will expire 5 years after enactment.
